Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Comprehensive Analysis of Long Term Ecological Research Survey
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will analyze results from a survey completed by diverse researchers to identify the research community's perceptions of the value of, and the need for, long-term research. The use of a broad-based survey to assess future research directions is novel in both ecology and evolutionary biology. Analyses of this survey will advance fundamental research by identifying new questions that require long-term research, opportunities that will promote more long-term research in the future, and the barriers that prevent scientists from engaging in long-term research projects. Findings will direct future research and funding priorities. The project will support two early-career researchers whose interests lie in linking fundamental research to societal needs and benefits.

A survey to assess researchers' opinions about long-term ecological research received nearly 1,200 responses from scientists nationwide. Responses represent the views of a large proportion of practicing researchers and scientists within the fields of ecology and evolutionary biology, including researchers who are not currently engaged in long-term research. Analyses of the resulting data will stimulate and redirect long-term ecological research within these fields. The researchers will conduct a comprehensive analysis of quantitative (ordinal and categorical) questions and qualitative (open-ended) questions using standard social science methods. Analyses will be primarily quantitative, including descriptive characterization of responses and comparison of mean responses among subgroups of respondents to test for differences. Open-ended questions used to solicit research priorities, opportunities, and barriers will be transformed into categorical variables using thematic coding; these variables will then be analyzed quantitatively. Survey analysis will include both a broad categorization of the views of the field as a whole as well as an exploration of differences in opinions and priorities based on respondent subfield, experience, institution type, and geographic focus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to analyze an extensive dataset of responses to a national survey assessing ecologists’ and evolutionary biologists’ views on the necessity and future of long-term research studies. The Long-Term Ecological Research (LTER) survey is the first attempt at a national assessment of the ecology and evolutionary biology fields’ views of long-term research. The LTER Survey was part of an NSF-funded initiative to identify and prioritize future directions for long-term ecological research.

Throughout fall/winter of 2015 and spring of 2016, Adam Reimer (PI) and Sara Kuebbing (Co-PI) analyzed survey data using qualitative and quantitative methods. The survey contained several open-ended questions where respondents could provide responses in words or phrases. We used a thematic coding approach to categorize and analyze these responses. Following coding, we analyzed survey responses to identify major questions to be addressed through long-term research, opportunities for future research, and barriers to conducting that research. We analyzed survey data to identify trends in responses based on demographics of respondents and opinions about various aspects of long-term ecological research.

There was a high level of agreement about the most significant questions to be addressed through long-term ecological research. Many respondents pointed to long-term research as best able to investigate the impact of global change drivers—including climate change, invasion, and anthropogenic disturbance—on populations, communities, and ecosystems and evolutionary processes. Nearly 60% of respondents indicated some form of global change driver as a key component of future LTER. Evolutionary dynamics, especially the interaction between evolutionary and ecological processes, were also a significant area of interest, though not as frequently mentioned as ecosystem, community, or population-level dynamics (11.3% of respondents). Water resource impacts (5.6%), conservation (5.1%), and coupled human-natural systems (12.5%) were also frequently mentioned as key areas for long-term research.

Respondents pointed to several key barriers to participating in long-term research. By far the largest barrier cited was the lack of funding compared with other forms of research. Many researchers pointed out that most research funding in the US and internationally focuses on the traditional 3-5 year research time span, leaving large-scale, long-term research underfunded and inconsistently funded. There are also logistical barriers to long-term research, including lack of physical facilities and infrastructure at long-term field sites, data sharing from existing long-term studies, difficulties in accessing research sites or facilities, and the inherent technical complexities of carrying out long-term research. Long-term research often requires special skills, dedicated and stable personnel, and access to data that can be difficult to access, especially for early career researchers.

Respondents pointed out many advantages available to researchers who seek to engage in long-term research. Many researchers pointed to the availability of funding targeted at long-term research, particularly through NSF, as well as a small support structure for supporting long-term research efforts. Respondents also pointed to the potential impact provided by long-term research, both in terms of its applicability to key challenges facing society, especially big, complex issues such as the effect of global change drivers on systems, as well as its potential positive impact on a researcher’s career. Respondents indicated that long term research had contributed significantly to the fields of ecosystem, community, and population ecology, more so than in evolutionary biology/ecology or landscape ecology. Respondents overwhelmingly agreed that long-term research was better equipped to address certain types of questions than short-term research. Nearly all respondents agreed that long-term changes to complex ecological systems are often unpredictable, highlighting the need for long-term study of responses to experimental manipulations.

The responses to this survey indicate that scientists perceive the value of long-term research to be high, but that the costs of engaging in long-term research are too high for early career scientists. Long-term research is capable of generating important insights into ecological systems in ways that site-based, short term research cannot. Many of these questions represent some of the most pressing contemporary ecological questions facing society, including the short- and long-term effects of human-induced global change. Many respondents indicated that they view long-term research as some of the most professionally and personally rewarding forms of ecological research. Despite its high potential value, the scientists in this survey indicate that long term research is still somewhat undervalued institutionally, which manifests as limited funding compared with shorter term research and career barriers that are particularly acute for beginning scientists. Opportunities to increase the viability of long-term research includes increased funding opportunities and especially funding that spans longer timeframes that traditional short-term research, promotion of the involvement of early-career researchers at well-established long-term research sites with ample infrastructure and previous data, and the education of the public on the importance of long term research for solving current environmental crises.
